resources.string: Rate this app on Google Play
This app includes a range of calculators to determine and convert resistance values for color-band resistors, SMD resistors, and more, supporting various resistor configurations and coding formats.
All calculations follow IEC 60062 and IEC 60063 standards for resistor color codes and preferred values to ensure precision and accuracy.
Use the color code chart to translate each band into its exact resistance value.
"Tap \"Validate\" to see if your resistance matches a standard E‑series value for the chosen tolerance."
Your resistance value is part of the %1$s series.
Your value is not in the E-series
With the selected tolerance, the closest E-series value is %1$s.
Adjust your selection to use a supported tolerance for a %1$s-band resistor.
Learn how 3‑ and 4‑digit markings on SMD resistors correspond to resistance and tolerance.
Discover how series & parallel formulas determine total resistance.

"The resistor color code system, standardized by IEC 60062, uses colored bands to represent a resistor's value, tolerance, and, in some cases, temperature coefficient. This method enables compact and quick identification of resistor specifications."
Each color corresponds to a specific value, depending on its position on the resistor body. The standard colors and their corresponding values are displayed in the table below.
Three-band resistors have two significant figure bands and one multiplier band. If the tolerance is not indicated, it is typically assumed to be ±20%.
Four-band resistors are the most common type. They have two significant figure bands, one multiplier band, and one tolerance band, which is typically larger than the other bands.
Five-band resistors are used for higher precision. They have three significant figure bands, one multiplier band, and one tolerance band. These resistors are sometimes blue.

Six-band resistors offer high precision and include a sixth band that represents the temperature coefficient (ppm/°C). This value indicates how much the resistance changes with temperature — for example, 100 ppm/°C means the resistance changes by 0.01% for every 1°C change in temperature.
"Green[5], Blue[6], Black[0], Brown[×10], Red[±2%], Brown[100 ppm/°C]"

The IEC 60062 standard defines code markings for resistors. It uses alphanumeric codes to represent resistance values in a compact format, making it suitable for marking small components, such as SMD (Surface-Mount Device) resistors.
SMD resistors use different coding systems based on the number of digits or characters used. The most common coding standards are:

The three-digit code is similar to the resistor color code system. The first two digits represent the significant figures, and the third digit is the multiplier. The general format can be expressed as:
For example, a resistor labeled 472 equates to:
The four-digit code is used for high-precision resistors. The first three digits represent the significant figures, and the fourth digit is the multiplier. The general format can be expressed as:
For example, a resistor labeled 1201 equates to:
"The letter 'R' indicates the position of the decimal point for resistance values lower than 10 \u03A9. For example, 0R5 would be 0.5 \u03A9 and 0R01 would be 0.01 \u03A9."

The EIA-96 code is a two-digit code followed by a letter, used for precision resistors with 1% tolerance. The two digits represent a value in the E-96 series, while the letter indicates the multiplier. The general format can be expressed as:
For example, a resistor labeled 43C equates to:
The multiplier indicates the factor by which to multiply the significant figures. In the EIA-96 code, letters represent multipliers as follows:

"These are the common resistance value codes, but a manufacturer may use a variation on these or even something completely different. It is therefore always important to verify the manufacturer's marking system."

"The IEC 60063 standard defines 'preferred values' or the 'E-series' system which standardizes resistor values by spacing them on a logarithmic scale. This makes mass production and inventory management far simpler, since manufacturers only need to stock a small set of values instead of every possible resistance."

Each E–series (E–6, E–12, E–24, etc.), corresponds to the number of values per decade (e.g. 6 values between 1–10 Ω for E–6). Higher series numbers yield finer precision. You can compute the n-th value in an E‑series with the formula
The E-6 series is typically used for 3-band resistors, offering less precision.
The E-12 and E-24 series are used for 4-band resistors, providing better precision.
The E-48, E-96, and E-192 series are used for 5 and 6-band resistors, providing high precision with tolerances as low as 0.05%. These series also introduce a third significant digit.

The information provided here regarding IEC standards is intended for general guidance. Please note that not all components may strictly adhere to these standards, as manufacturers may have variations or different interpretations. Always consult the specific datasheet or contact the manufacturer directly if you are unsure about the specifications or standards for a particular component.

When resistors are connected in series, the same current flows through each one, and the supply voltage is divided across them in proportion to their resistance. The total resistance is the sum of all individual resistances.
However, for two resistors in series the total resistance can be written concisely as:

When resistors are connected in parallel, the voltage across each resistor is the same, and the total current is the sum of the currents through each branch. The reciprocal of the total resistance equals the sum of reciprocals of each resistor.
Alternatively, the parallel resistance can be expressed as:
There is also a two-resistor shortcut for parallel resistors, which can be written as:
